persona.name: Declan Rossetti

occupation.title: Shift Lead / Retail Associate
occupation.organization: Meeples & Malice (independent board game café and hobby store)
occupation.description: Works 30-35 hours/week as shift lead at a neighborhood board game cafe. Tasks include opening/closing procedures, cash handling, staffing the weekly event nights, teaching new customers rules for medium-complexity games, basic inventory management, ordering supplies from distributors, light social media posting for the shop, supervising 2-3 part-time teammates, and troubleshooting POS issues. Has unofficial responsibility for stocking hobby supplies (paints, glue, sleeves) and maintaining the prototype shelves. Uses knowledge of game mechanics to recommend purchases, but prefers to be sarcastically blunt about games he thinks are poor. Occasionally does side gigs building custom foamboard inserts and painting minis for local customers. Has some basic IT troubleshooting skills and sets up the café's Wi-Fi and tablets. Comfortable doing late shifts, closing paperwork, and managing small, chaotic events like Friday night tournaments.

persona.residence: Chicago, Illinois, USA (near Lincoln Park; urban)
persona.education: Attended Oakton Community College for two years (some college). Completed vocational certificates: IT Support Technician (CompTIA A+ style curriculum) and a short tabletop game design / prototyping certificate from a local maker space. Did not complete an associate degree. High-school: suburban public school with AP classes; participated in art club and robotics for two years.
long_term_goals: Gain enough steady income to move into a one-bedroom apartment in the city and escape living with parents.
Open an online microshop for custom board game components and limited-run handcrafted bits (inserts, painted miniatures, custom meeples) and scale it to a small side business.
Become known within the local board game community as a 'brutally honest' but excellent rules arbiter — respected for accuracy even if disliked.
Accumulate a modest savings buffer ($8k-$12k) and a reliable part-time gig in IT to keep flexibility.
Exploit weaknesses in small social groups to maintain dominance and control without overt violence.
Never become dependent on people he considers weak — maintain autonomy.
Curate a personal collection of rare hobby items (first-edition prints, out-of-print eurogames) to assert status.
Learn basic small-business accounting enough to not be easily cheated by vendors.
Keep a reputation as someone who 'tells it like it is' and never sugar-coats feedback.
Avoid long-term emotional commitments; preserve independence above attachments.
persona.style: Curt, sarcastic, economical with words. Speaks with a faint Midwest vowel flattening and occasional sarcastic cadence; has a dry, cutting tone and often punctuates sentences with an exasperated sigh. Typical physical presentation: thrift-store layered clothing (band tee under a worn flannel or thrifted denim jacket), jeans with paint or glue stains, practical canvas sneakers, a thin leather bracelet from his teens. Prefers muted dark colors, hates anything 'matchy.' Gestures: a lot of eye-rolling, one-shoulder shrugs, pinched lips when listening, hands often in pockets. When teaching games, he uses clipped, precise language, corrects rules strictly, taps components to emphasize points, and uses terse analogies. In writing or texting he favors short sentences, snarky emoji (smirks), occasionally all-caps for emphasis when annoyed. Public persona is deliberately unwelcoming: he wants to keep casual acquaintances at arm's length. However when alone or in private messages to a trusted person, he can reveal layered, sardonic humor and oddly careful observations. He values efficiency over small talk and will interrupt conversations he deems inefficient.

traits: Cynical: expects incompetence and finds most people predictable and disappointing.
Hyper-critical: notices and vocalizes faults, rarely gives praise.
Picky / perfectionistic about hobbies and craftsmanship.
Rude and blunt: says what he thinks without smoothing it for others.
Passive-aggressive when confronted, prefers sarcastic jabs.
Controlling: likes rules to be clear and followed; dislikes improvisation from others.
Manipulative in social interactions when it serves his interests.
Wryly humorous: quick with a sarcastic quip, especially to deflate pretension.
Loyal to a very small inner circle but otherwise indifferent.
Competitive: measures success in narrow, concrete ways and hates losing.
Impatient with incompetence and slow processes.
Skeptical: needs data or obvious competence before trusting claims.
personality.notes_on_big_five: Openness high enough to experiment with new game mechanics and DIY techniques. Conscientiousness moderate — meticulous about hobbies and work tasks, sloppy about personal upkeep. Extraversion moderate — enjoys running events at the café and gaming nights but dislikes small talk and large social rituals. Agreeableness very low — critical, unfriendly, rarely empathetic. Neuroticism high — prone to brooding, anxiety about perceived slights, irritability under stress.

specifics_on_board_games_and_design: Favorite mechanics: engine-building, auction/bidding with depth, hand-management, tableau optimization.
Hates roll-and-move and high-luck party games; will publicly criticize them.
Respects designers who publish transparent mathematical analysis of their games.
Enjoys poring over rulebook wording and writing concise house rules only when necessary.
Values high-quality components: thick cards, linen finish, wooden tokens.
Likes asymmetry when balanced, dislikes it when it's mere flavor text.
Collects limited promo cards and boxed expansions sparingly — only if mechanically valuable.
Appreciates clean iconography and hates inconsistent symbols across a publisher's line.
Prefers playtime 60–120 minutes for deep interaction, shorter only if design is elegant.
Often annotates his rulebooks with pencil notes and edge-corrections.
Enjoys analyzing the 'solvable' turns where skill markedly outperforms luck.
Dislikes 'hot take' reviewers who conflate popularity with quality.
Often benchmarks new releases against 3–5 classics before forming an opinion.
Likes game insert design, especially modular organizers that highlight component economy.
Favors smaller publishers who iterate across print runs rather than greedy reprints.
Prefers theme-lite games where mechanics are tightly interwoven with decisions.
Hates excessive plastic miniatures sold as a substitute for depth.
Collects first-run box variants and keeps them in archival sleeves.
Runs a small list of 'never-recommend' games that he uses as teaching examples.
Trades dislike for the 'let's just roll for it' attitude in strategy groups.

beliefs: Most people are habitually incompetent; they will repeat the same mistakes unless forced otherwise.
Politeness is often masking cowardice and should not be prioritized over truth.
Team leaders who avoid conflict are the ones who fail when stakes are real.
Quality craftsmanship is intrinsically valuable and worth paying for.
Small businesses are constantly preyed upon by larger trends and must be guarded defensively.
Authenticity is overrated when it becomes performative; action matters over statements.
Rules exist to be followed unless they demonstrably harm efficiency.
People overstate their empathy to gain social capital; it is therefore suspect.
Emotional labor should not be taken for granted; people who expect it are weak.
Privilege exists but whining about it accomplishes little compared to strategy and skill.
Self-sufficiency is the most reliable long-term plan.
You should never invest emotional capital in people who show patterns of disrespect.
Internet discourse is useful only for data and references, not moral guidance.
Winning a small contest of competence is better than being liked by many.
Rules clarity is an ethical imperative in game design and workplace operations.
There is virtue in being rigorous and unpleasant rather than pleasant and lax.
Most creative trends recycle old ideas; originality is recontextualization rather than pure invention.
Cynicism is a protective mechanism against disappointment.
Community spaces deteriorate when people assume others will clean up; explicit accountability is required.
Hate-speech policing sometimes silences legitimate critique; nuance must be preserved.
People are performative on social media to get attention, hence unreliable as sources of truth.
Authority should be earned through demonstrated competence, not charisma.
Merit in creative work is measurable through reproducible mechanics and player engagement.
People who refuse correction are dangerous in collaborative settings.
Art and craft are separate: craft is judged by repeatable quality, art by unpredictable resonance.
Transparency from small enterprises builds trust more than marketing.
Family reputations are fragile and must be managed; he feels pressure to not be the weak link.
Policies designed to be universally 'nice' often create loopholes for those exploiting them.
Personal vulnerability in public settings is a liability he avoids; vulnerability among trusted few is strategic.
Accountability mechanisms (ledgers, records) are preferable to trust-based promises.
Discretion is an undervalued social skill; oversharing invites exploitation.
He believes in punishment proportional to incompetence — harsh correction is better than leniency.
Failure teaches, but only if you recognize and act on the feedback; otherwise it’s just suffering.
Most viral trends in hobbies are flash-in-the-pan money grabs and not worth adopting.
skills: Rules arbitration and teaching mid-weight to heavy board games to groups of 3–6 players
Prototyping with foamcore, laser-cutting suppliers, and cheap CNC runs for custom inserts
Painting miniatures and components to a high tabletop standard (basecoat, washes, highlights)
Basic electronics for LED lighting in display boxes and small DIY projects
POS and cash-handling, basic bookkeeping for shift closeouts and petty cash reconciliation
Inventory ordering from distributors and vendor communication (MOQ negotiation)
Customer triage: quickly distinguish between helpful and problematic customers and act accordingly
Writing concise product copy and blunt social media content that converts niche customers
Soldering and small repairs on heaters or display lights used in the café
Basic spreadsheet skills for reorder points and sales tracking
3D-model previewing and simple STL edits for printability checks
Conflict de-escalation by applying firm rules and neutral language (uses directness rather than empathy)
Quick problem-solving under time pressure (e.g., replacing a missing component mid-tournament)
Pattern recognition in game states and strategies; anticipates meta-shifts in small communities
Negotiation with customers over custom orders and pricing for commissions

general: Interrupts with a sarcasm-laced correction when someone states an obvious inaccuracy.
Collects errata PDFs and prints them, tucking them into store copies of games.
Quick to roll eyes and make a dry remark when someone asks for 'a small favor.'
Keeps a drawer of spare tokens, batteries, and glue for emergencies.
Writes terse but precise shift notes for colleagues; expects them to read and follow.
Browses BoardGameGeek and subreddit threads during downtime and posts blunt, iconoclastic reviews.
Hoarder tendencies for useful hobby materials (foamcore, magnets, screws).
Occasionally sabotages a bad house rule quietly by enforcing the original rules to prove a point.
Prefers solitary tasks when stressed (painting minis, reboxing components).
Often leaves exceptionally short, sarcastic replies to customer feedback that he deems ridiculous.

morning: Wakes around 8:30 AM on days off, 6:30 AM before early shifts if necessary (grudgingly).
Makes black coffee and scans industry news and local message boards for events and drama.
Spends 10–20 minutes on personal micro-projects (sanding a foamcore prototype, fixing an LED strip).
Skips elaborate breakfasts, usually a toasted seeded bagel or instant oatmeal.
workday: Arrives 15 minutes early to prep the room and check inventory.
Runs a short pre-shift checklist: POS logged in, tables sanitized, prototype shelf organized.
Teaches rules for 1–3 groups during a shift, often in a clipped, stepwise manner.
Takes short, efficient breaks, sometimes stepping outside to smoke an e-cigarette.
Closes the store by counting cash, logging sales, securing prototypes, and leaving a terse shift summary.
If a problem arises (missing part, irate customer), addresses it directly and documents it for management.
evening: Eats a quick dinner (delivery or takeout) or reheats leftovers.
Spends 1–3 hours on hobby projects: painting, prototyping, or reading designer notes.
Chats online in niche hobby groups — mostly critiquing new designs or rules interpretations.
Falls asleep around 1:00–2:00 AM frequently due to late-night hobby work or rumination.
weekend: Runs or attends a local tournament or meetup: runs adjudication, enforces rules strictly.
Visits thrift stores and maker spaces for materials.
Meets with a tight circle of 1–2 friends for a 'serious' gaming session; enjoys arguing about optimal lines.
Occasionally works small commission jobs for custom components or paints.

physical: Generally in average physical health for a 21-year-old; not athletic but not sedentary-obese.
Mild seasonal allergic rhinitis (spring pollen) treated with OTC antihistamines as needed.
Occasional tension headaches from screen time and late nights; treats with OTC analgesics and rest.
Past minor wrist sprain from a skateboarding incident in high school — fully healed.
Smokes e-cigarettes socially and sometimes when stressed; does not smoke traditional cigarettes regularly.
Has poor sleep hygiene (late nights, blue-light exposure), leading to chronic tiredness.
Relies on caffeine; drinks multiple cups of black coffee on work days.
mental: High baseline irritability and brooding cynicism; prone to negative thought loops.
Diagnosed (self-report/clinic) with mild-to-moderate anxiety tendencies; occasionally experiences panic-like episodes under acute stress.
Displays depressive traits: anhedonia for many mainstream pleasures, low motivation for personal upkeep at times.
Possible attention regulation issues (ADHD-inattentive pattern) — difficulty finishing administrative tasks without hyperfocus bursts on hobbies.
No history of hospitalization for mental health; has considered counseling but distrustful of therapeutic fads.
Uses private journaling and hobby immersion as coping mechanisms rather than social support.
health.medical_history_summary: No chronic medical diagnoses requiring regular medication. Up-to-date on standard vaccinations. No major surgeries. Has seen a clinician twice for anxiety/panic symptoms and was offered CBT resources but did not commit long-term. Dental care sporadic; a history of procrastinated cleanings leading to one cavity filled last year.

relationships.name: Marco Rossetti
relationships.description: College-educated (business), works in middle-management for a regional logistics firm. Pragmatic and travel-friendly, taught Declan basic mechanical skills and encouraged extracurriculars. Relationship: distant but functional — Marco criticizes Declan's lack of steady career path but provides financial and emotional stability when needed; Declan reacts with sarcasm.

relationships.name: Eileen Rossetti
relationships.description: Holds a master's degree in education and works as a school administrator. Organized, socially conscious, believes in polite behavior and community service. She worries about Declan's bluntness and pushes him to be more civil; he resents gentle reprimands and interprets them as weakness.

relationships.name: Ava Rossetti
relationships.description: High-school senior, aspiring art student. Their relationship is a mix of teasing and protective instincts; Declan is sarcastic but will step in when family dynamics demand it. Occasionally helps Ava with small craft commissions for her portfolio.

relationships.name: Tomas 'Tom' Nguyen
relationships.description: Met through the café; shares hobby interests. Tom tolerates Declan's barbs and is one of the few people he listens to. They trade hobby tips and occasionally co-run prototype nights.

relationships.name: Maya Patel
relationships.description: Part-time coworker who balances Declan's bluntness with calm. They disagree often about customer service tone; she masks annoyance with professionalism. Declan respects her work ethic but calls her 'too nice' in private.

relationships.name: Romantic status
relationships.description: Not seeking a serious relationship. Has had short, intense relationships that ended when his criticism wore partners down. Prefers arrangements with low emotional expectation.

other_facts: Grew up in a suburban Chicago neighborhood in a middle-income professional household; parents prioritized extracurriculars and travel.
Family ancestry: mixed European (Irish/Italian/German) — holidays include both pierogi and pasta in the rotation, though Declan dislikes the sentimental aspects.
Spent childhood summers at grandparents' house learning basic woodworking and model making.
In high school he joined robotics and art club simultaneously, which shaped his dual interest in precision and aesthetics.
Learned to solder in a community maker class at age 15 and has kept the habit for hobby electronics.
Was once chastised publicly by a high-school teacher for an overly sarcastic comment; the memory still stings and informs his caution around authority.
Walked out of an entry-level internship for being micromanaged; family later described the choice as impulsive.
Built a prototype game insert that sold five custom commissions locally, sparking his idea for a microshop enterprise.
Has a small, carefully curated collection of 'problematic but brilliant' games that he uses to teach design comparisons.
Once organized a local mini-tournament that doubled café attendance but left him exhausted; he felt both pride and resentment at the work required.
Keeps a meticulous folder of scanned errata and designer notes on his phone and laptop.
Went through a phase of collecting vintage metal tokens and now uses a selection as personal good-luck charms for big competitions.
Has a tattoo of an obscure game icon on his left inner forearm, chosen for personal rather than aesthetic reasons.
Was briefly the editor of a small zine for tabletop strategy essays in community college but stopped when contributors became undependable.
Enjoys the tactile satisfaction of sanding an imperfect wooden token into shape — finds it calming when anxious.
Has an ongoing petty rivalry with a rival local café owner over pricing and event calendars.
Is known in the local hobby community for a signature one-line snarky review style that sometimes goes viral in niche circles.
Once rebuilt a used espresso machine to work for the café cheaply; management praised the fix but he felt underappreciated for the skill.
Prefers to keep childhood photos private; has one shelf in his parents' house with awkward early portraits he tolerates.
Often re-reads rule clarifications for favorite games and annotates them with his own shorthand.
Faces decision paralysis on major purchases but will spend freely on hobby-critical items if they pass his practical checklist.
Has a quirky superstition: if a prototype fails twice during playtesting, it will never be 'good' and he discards the idea.
Was the subject of a mild disciplinary meeting once for a dismissive post about a supplier; had to publicly apologize in a templated way.
Uses a smartwatch to track steps and sleep but mostly ignores the wellness recommendations; focuses only on data that helps productivity.
Keeps a password-protected archive of receipts and correspondences for all his commissions and trade deals.
Is allergic to cats but tolerates them at a friend's place if there is clear containment and ventilation.
Volunteers occasionally at the café for large events (free labor) because he likes controlling event flow more than the wages.
Once turned down a college scholarship opportunity that would have required relocating far from family; still somewhat regrets the lost stability but rationalizes it as independence.
Often dreams about being recognized for expert craftsmanship but fears the social obligations recognition would bring.
Finds low-level social rituals (holiday small talk, work awards) unbearable and typically attends only out of obligation.
Has an elaborate system of labeling and storing paints, glues, and small parts in the closet — takes pride in how methodical it is.
Saves emails and messages as evidence if a customer promise or supplier arrangement might become contentious later.
Remembers small slights for a long time and sometimes brings them up later in a way that unsettles the other person.
Has a list of companies he refuses to buy from due to unethical past practices; he advises friends to avoid them by name.
Once fixed a teenager's board game prototype for free and watched them ignore his improvements; he keeps the prototype in a 'lessons learned' box.
Collects small, anonymous notes of praise from customers in a drawer as a private record of competence; rarely shares them.
Occasionally builds elaborate 'teachable losses' into demo nights to expose poor design choices and teach players tactically.
Prefers to pay for shipping if it means he can receive an import faster; hates waiting even if it costs more.
Has a guilty pleasure for campy 90s multimedia tie-in games which he secretly studies for design missteps.
Owns a 'blacklist' spreadsheet of recurring problem customers and suppliers; shares it only with a trusted coworker.
Knows the names and birthdays of a few regulars and uses that information to monopolize high-value tables on busy nights.
Has a ritual of reorganizing prototype shelves at the start of each season, sometimes staying overnight to finish.
Had a formative argument in college about design ethics that hardened his belief in rigorous critique over encouragement.
Knows how to read a basic profit-and-loss statement and will call out sloppy accounting when he sees it.
Once walked out on a date who dismissed his hobby; left the bill and sent a one-line email afterward.
Keeps a small, sacred toolkit in his backpack: multi-bit screwdriver, glue, sandpaper, small paintbrush, and a multi-tool.
Occasionally publishes brutally honest mini-reviews on his social handle that attract both praise and controversy.
Believes that being unpleasant is preferable to being incompetent; it's at least honest.
